subject: Re: [junit] Literate asserts
msgSnippet: ... How about: assert(that(n).greaterThan(2).and().that(n).lessThan(10)) and I would have thought assert(that(n).greaterThan(2).and().lessThan(10)) should be
messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> It becomes very difficult to formulate expressions as soon as they are more
> complex than a simple equality or inequality. It's fine for "n > 2", not so
> much for "n > 2 && n < 10" and it's all downhill from there.
>
> The Java language also cripples this attempt by not allowing you to re-open
> existing classes (you can't say n.greaterThan(2).and().lessThan(10)), so you
> are forced to put your words and verbs in a certain order that is dictated
> by the Java syntax, and not by the developer.
>
How about:

assert(that(n).greaterThan(2).and().that(n).lessThan(10))

and I would have thought

assert(that(n).greaterThan(2).and().lessThan(10))

should be possible as well.

- Neil
